choices.B: Manually validate that the existing update is being performed.
choices.C: Test vulnerability remediation in a sandbox before deploying.
choices.A: Configure a script to automatically update the scanning tool.
choices.D: Configure vulnerability scans to run in credentialed mode.

questions.question_text: An analyst finds that unpatched servers have undetected vulnerabilities because the vulnerability scanner does not have the latest set of signatures. Management directed the security team to have personnel update the scanners with the latest signatures at least 24 hours before conducting any scans, but the outcome is unchanged. Which of the following is the BEST logical control to address the failure?

discussion.content: answer is A, its saying that action remained unchanged. sometimes automated processes help to resolve forgettable instructions.
Its A. This is all about updating the scan signatures. Similar Q in 002

The issue is deciding what "outcome" is. If "outcome" is the signatures still not being updated, then A is the answer. If it's just the scan in general even though the signatures are updated, then the answer is D. I don't like you CompTIA.

The answer is A. But I would like to understand why [I chose D originally]. This is what I gather. Correct me if I'm wrong.

B - Not logical "Manually" , The question asks for the best "Logical Control". Not sure if that's an important key word.
C - Doesn't really pertain to the question?
D - Credentialed scanning provides more accurate scanning to better identify weak configurations, missing patches and similar vulnerabilities. The question does not specifically state that the patches have been verified as implemented? So even if credentialed scanning takes place, if the patch is not applied, it doesn't mean shit.
A - Again, the question doesn't state that the patches have been implemented? So scripting would guarantee that is has been performed so it maintains consistency
D is correct. Because the Vuln scan was updated with the latest signature file.

Yeah. I support D as well. If an update 24hrs before vulnerability scan can't detect vulnerability, I don't think think automatic update will change anything. The only viable option is credential scan.
most vul. scanners have a automatic update feature for their feeds, Option D seems for me more correct

After analyzing and correlating activity from multiple sensors, the security analyst has determined a group from a high-risk country is responsible for a sophisticated breach of the company network and continuous administration of targeted attacks for the past three months. Until now, the attacks went unnoticed.
This is an example of:

correct
This question was in the exam :)
This question was in the exam :)
This is a call back, outbound. So c2 wont go inside, understand how c2 works via dns. Its always the botnet that will always talk to the mothership, not the other way around. The answer is D.
The answer is B - the adversary is trying to contact an internal endpoint. Similar Q in 002
Answer is B but It should be Inside compromised system trying to reach the command and control system.

comments.content: Then it conflicts with the answer B (from outside in).

discussion.content: Has to be D because of "call home".

comments.content: This is even mroe confusing. If you say "The malware is trying to reach the C2", it means the call home was made from the inside out, not from C2 to the infected computer inside the enterprise.

discussion.content: B is correct. The question did not specify which malware (remember all types of malware). The malware is trying to reach the command and control center where it was made to feed them with info from the system.

“Call home” messages would be something that bots would send to reach C&C via beaconing. 
D is a much better answer

The “call home�? message is indicative of beaconing. This usually occurs after a stage 1 malware has been implanted on a company’s workstation or server, but the more correct answer is that this infected system is running a command that is attempting to reach a botnet’s command and control server. This beaconing will continue until the infected host (workstation or server) is found and cleared of the malware, or until the botnet gives the infected host further instructions (such as to attack).

comments.content: for me Option D is better, malware running on any computer
Option "B " does not make sense for me, "Call home" malware is an internal host trying to reach a possible C&C outside, this either means there is malware on the network or ex filtration attempts
maybe if you check the supply of kfc

discussion.content: Wait, wouldn't this beaconing traffic be seen from an infected host towards a C&C server? Why would a C&C server try to reach an internal host? These type of attempts would be blocked? It would be folly to try? It doesn't say inbound activity anywhere either, right? Can anyone shed some light on this?

questions.question_text: A cybersecurity analyst has received an alert that well-known "call home" messages are continuously observed by network sensors at the network boundary. The proxy firewall successfully drops the messages. After determining the alert was a true positive, which of the following represents the MOST likely cause?

choices.A: Attackers are running reconnaissance on company resources.
choices.B: An outside command and control system is attempting to reach an infected system.
choices.D: Malware is running on a company system.
choices.C: An insider is trying to exfiltrate information to a remote network.

discussion.content: D. Lessons learned report Should be !
D. Lessons learned report
detailed information on when an incident was detected, how impactful the incident Was Lessons learned

any identified gaps needing improvement

These are the keywords here so its D.
The answer is D - Similar Q in 002
its obviously 4
D - It mentions analysis of how the incident was managed
I thought it was lessons learned.. starting to lose faith in this site

Definitely D. The lessons learned report provides you with the details of the incident, its severity, the remediation method, and most importantly, how effective your response was. Additionally, it provides recommendations for improvements in the future. A forensic analysis report would not provide recommendations for future improvements, even though it provides many of the other details.

comments.content:
"The Forensic Analysis step during IR is a process of analyzing and reviewing gathered data from different sources e.g. computer, log files, web history, email files, pictures & information for users using tools to gather info such a asset IDs, serial numbers, arrival and depature times, transport routing #, name/tile handlers and location.

Forensic Analysis should also help determine victims/attackers, the what, who and where, and how the incident was done. Forensic Analysis enable us to go through and create a case against the attacker during the investigation process."

Dale Meredith
Performing Incident Response and Handling (Pluiralsight course)

discussion.content:
somebody help me: Does forensic report really include how the incident was remediated, how impactful the incident was to the victim, as well as how effective the remedy response was?
I thought these are all part of lessons learned?

Please note the word "detailed." 

The answer is A. https://www.sans.org/blog/intro-to-report-writing-for-digital-forensics/

 Leessons-learned report are usually brief renditions of participants' input from the standpoint of their own observation. These are then discussed during review sessions and edited accordingly.

comments.content: I think the answer is lesson learned simply because a forensic report focuses on reporting evidence and steps taken to collect those evidence and it is for legal purposes. It shouldn't have information about the impact of the incident nor how it was remediated.

discussion.content: the answer is D.

questions.question_text: Which of the following items represents a document that includes detailed information on when an incident was detected, how impactful the incident was, and how it was remediated, in addition to incident response effectiveness and any identified gaps needing improvement?

discussion.content: Isn't this C? The offending code is from the company's website. Updating the browser's GPO will only fix the issue within the company since they will be the one's in scope for the GPO change. However, users accessing the website outside the company, and using their personal devices are still at risk. So I think, its best to address the root cause and have the developer review the code, and implement the fix.

comments.content: Yes. I second this thought. GPO only addresses this on a PC you manage.. Since the question does not identify this as an intranet site, reviewing code and implementing a fix is the "BEST" answer.

if the offending code contained the syntax <input autocomplete="on"> then C would have been the right answer. Take note that the vulnerability reported could be false and the only way to verify this is by reviewing the code itself. Having said this using GPO is the right answer

discussion.content:
Lol guys stop arguing its A.

https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/issues/4215

major browsers will override any use of autocomplete="off" then zap retire that plugin https://github.com/zaproxy/zap-extensions/pull/1233

The answer here is C. 
This a coding issue with the application. 
You can set a GPO but the app will still be an issue. 
Similar Q in 002
Same question on Jason Dion tutorials and answer is C.
It should be C. What about users outside the network? If they save passwords and their machines are infected, attackers will have access to their credentials.

comments.content: if the offending code contained the syntax <input autocomplete="on"> then C would have been the right answer. Take note that the vulnerability reported could be false and the only way to verify this is by reviewing the code itself. Having said this using GPO is the right answer

discussion.content:
C should be correct
https://www.w3schools.com/tags/att_input_autocomplete.asp

The code is not necessarily incorrect as developers can still reference the 'passwword' name correctly in their code. Its just blatantly spelt wrong. You wouldn't know this if you did not have experience building logic for a 'front-end' component in a webpage. The misspelling is a trap feature in the question. The question is about the Auto complete feature which should be disabled in the browser. D GPO Change is correct.
i guessed 4 and i got it right so i think it is 4 becauise the website sasid it was and the internet is very smart

I think this is indeed D, for the following reason: The AUTOCOMPLETE option set to disable is seldom followed-up on by modern browsers anyway. I think the goal here is to prevent an attacker from being able harvest company credentials on an infected machine. So from a security perspective, it would be better to disable autocompletion in the Browser settings, than doing it on the company website knowing full well that doesn't usually work.

choices.C: The developer should review the code and implement a code fix.
choices.D: The organization should update the browser GPO to resolve the issue.
choices.B: The system administrator should disable SSL and implement TLS.
choices.A: The analyst should implement a scanner exception for the false positive.
